sect1.title: Adminmenu
sect1.para: Most aspect of the Libranet network configuration can be configured through the Network & Internet tab in Adminmenu.

The Network & Internet page contains these items:
Edit network configuration: This item is used to configure various kinds of network interfaces, for example LAN, DSL, Cable, PPPoE, Wireless and dial-up connections.
Network configuration wizard: This item will try to configure network interfaces automatically.
Set hostname: With this item you can set the system hostname.
Configure firewall: With this item you can configure the Libranet firewall. A firewall is used to block connections from or to a system that are not authorized, and internet connection sharing (NAT) can be switched on in the firewall configuration.
Configure NdisWrapper: You can install Windows XP NDIS drivers for wireless cards with this item.

sect2.title: Setting the system hostname
sect2.para: A hostname is a unique name that identifies the system. This can be any name that contains alphanumeric characters, for example: linux.home. If you are going to use the system as a server, you should use a fully qualified domain name (FQDN). This is a name that consists of a hostname part, a domain name, and a top-level domain. For example, mindbender.example.org is a FQDN, in which mindbender is the hostname, example is the domain name, and org is the top-level domain.
You can change the current hostname of a machine with the Set hostname item in the Network & Internet page in adminmenu.
After clicking on the Set hostname item, a dialog with the current hostname will appear (. You can change the hostname in the input field, and save the change by clicking on the Set Hostname button.

sect2.title: Setting up ethernet cards
sect2.para: Ethernet cards can be configured with the Edit network configuration item that is available through the Network & Internet tab in Adminmenu.

sect2.title: Configuring DNS
sect2.para: DNS servers have a very special task in networking. They translate hostnames (for instance www.libranet.com) to IP addresses. To be able to use hostnames the system needs access to one or more DNS servers. Almost all Internet service providers provide DNS servers. DNS can be configured per interface via the Network configuration item in Adminmenu. To change the DNS server for an interface, select the network connection, and click on Edit connection properties. The DNS settings are then available under the DNS tab (). You can add a DNS server with the Add button, or remove the selected server with the Delete button.

sect1.title: Manual configuration
sect1.para: This chapter explains how some common network-related configuration files work. Most things can be configured with adminmenu, but more experienced users might prefer configuring things by editing the relevant configuration files.

sect2.title: Configuring nameservers
sect2.para: The name resolver is configured using the /etc/resolv.conf file. This file is dynamically generated, based on the interface settings. sect2.title: Local hosts
sect2.para: Besides resolving using name servers specified in /etc/resolv.conf, GNU/Linux can also resolve hosts that are specified in /etc/hosts. note.para: If you want to use the same hosts file on a relatively large number of machines, it might we worth looking at the dnsmasq package. Dnsmasq can provide a hosts file on one host to a complete network through its DNS server.
